metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: Explain the production of atomic absorption and emission line spectra, including those from metal vapour lamps

quantised_energy_levels.name: Quantised Energy Levels
quantised_energy_levels.correct: Electrons in atoms can only exist at specific, discrete energy levels. They cannot have energies between these levels.

continuous energy values.error: Electrons cannot have any energy they want.
continuous energy values.fix: Energy levels are quantised. Only certain specific values are allowed.
continuous energy values.action: Look at an energy level diagram. Notice the gaps between levels where electrons cannot exist.

any orbit distance.error: Confusing classical orbits with quantum energy states.
any orbit distance.fix: Quantum mechanics restricts electrons to specific energy states, not continuous orbital distances.
any orbit distance.action: Think of electron standing waves. Only certain wavelengths fit around the nucleus.

energy depends on temperature.error: Temperature affects which levels are occupied, not what levels exist.
energy depends on temperature.fix: Energy levels are fixed for each element. Temperature affects transitions between them.
energy depends on temperature.action: Compare cold vs hot hydrogen. Same energy levels, different populations.

persistent.gap: You are not accepting that electron energies are fundamentally discrete.
persistent.action: Review the Bohr model and electron standing waves. Quantisation is why atoms are stable.

ground_state.name: Ground State
ground_state.correct: The ground state is the lowest energy level an electron can occupy. Atoms naturally settle into this state.

highest energy level.error: Opposite. Ground state is the lowest, not highest.
highest energy level.fix: Ground means bottom. n = 1 is the lowest quantum number.
highest energy level.action: On an energy diagram, ground state is at the bottom.

zero energy.error: Ground state has energy, just the minimum possible.
zero energy.fix: Zero energy is typically defined as ionisation. Ground state energy is below this.
zero energy.action: Check hydrogen: ground state is 0 eV on some diagrams, -13.6 eV on others. Neither is truly zero.

unstable state.error: Ground state is the most stable, not unstable.
unstable state.fix: Excited states are unstable and decay. Ground state is where atoms rest.
unstable state.action: Atoms return to ground state after emitting photons. It is the stable endpoint.

persistent.gap: You are confusing ground state with excited states.
persistent.action: Ground = lowest energy = most stable = n = 1. Memorise this.

excited_state.name: Excited State
excited_state.correct: Excited states are higher energy levels above the ground state. Electrons reach them by absorbing energy.

ground state.error: Excited means higher than ground state.
ground state.fix: n = 2, 3, 4... are excited states. n = 1 is the ground state.
ground state.action: Excited electrons have absorbed energy. They are above the ground level.

stable state.error: Excited states are unstable and will decay.
stable state.fix: Electrons in excited states quickly drop back down, emitting photons.
stable state.action: Excited states have short lifetimes, typically nanoseconds. Ground state is stable.

ionised state.error: Ionisation means the electron has left the atom entirely.
ionised state.fix: Excited electrons are still bound to the atom, just at higher energy levels.
ionised state.action: Excited = still bound but elevated. Ionised = electron removed completely.

persistent.gap: You are not distinguishing excited states from ground state or ionisation.
persistent.action: Draw an energy diagram. Mark ground, excited, and ionisation clearly.

emission_mechanism.name: Emission Mechanism
emission_mechanism.correct: When an electron transitions from a higher to a lower energy level, it emits a photon with energy equal to the difference.

lower to higher level.error: Going up requires absorbing energy, not emitting.
lower to higher level.fix: Emission occurs when electrons drop DOWN in energy.
lower to higher level.action: Think of a ball falling. It releases energy. Electrons emit photons when falling to lower levels.

photon absorbed.error: Absorption and emission are opposite processes.
photon absorbed.fix: Emission releases a photon. Absorption takes one in.
photon absorbed.action: Downward arrow on energy diagram = emission. Upward = absorption.

electron emitted.error: Confusing photon emission with electron ejection.
electron emitted.fix: The electron stays in the atom but moves to a lower level. A photon is emitted.
electron emitted.action: Emission spectra involve photons, not electrons leaving.

persistent.gap: You are confusing the direction of transitions and what is emitted.
persistent.action: Down = photon out. Up = photon in. Practise with energy diagrams.

absorption_mechanism.name: Absorption Mechanism
absorption_mechanism.correct: When an electron absorbs a photon with exactly the right energy, it transitions from a lower to a higher energy level.

higher to lower level.fix: Absorption requires going UP in energy by absorbing a photon.
higher to lower level.action: Think of a ball being lifted. It gains energy. Electrons absorb photons to rise.

any photon energy works.error: Only photons matching the energy gap can be absorbed.
any photon energy works.fix: Photon energy must exactly match the difference between energy levels.
any photon energy works.action: If the photon energy does not match any gap, it passes through unchanged.

photon emitted.error: Absorption takes in a photon, not releases one.
photon emitted.fix: Absorb = photon disappears into the atom. Emit = photon comes out.
photon emitted.action: Upward arrow on energy diagram = absorption.

persistent.gap: You are confusing absorption with emission.
persistent.action: Absorption = photon in, electron goes up. Emission = photon out, electron goes down.

photon_energy_transition.name: Photon Energy Equals Transition Energy
photon_energy_transition.correct: The energy of the emitted or absorbed photon exactly equals the energy difference between the two levels involved.

photon energy equals level energy.error: Photon energy is the difference, not the level itself.
photon energy equals level energy.fix: Eph = E_final - E_initial for absorption, or E_initial - E_final for emission.
photon energy equals level energy.action: Calculate: if electron goes from 12.1 eV to 10.2 eV, photon = 1.9 eV.

photon energy is arbitrary.error: Photon energy is precisely determined by the energy levels.
photon energy is arbitrary.fix: Only certain photon energies are possible because only certain level differences exist.
photon energy is arbitrary.action: This is why we get line spectra, not continuous spectra.

photon energy equals ionisation energy.error: That only applies to ionisation from ground state.
photon energy equals ionisation energy.fix: Most transitions involve smaller energy differences between bound states.
photon energy equals ionisation energy.action: Check the formula: Eph = ŒîE, the difference between any two levels.

persistent.gap: You are not calculating transition energies correctly.
persistent.action: Practice: for any transition, photon energy = |E_upper - E_lower|.

line_vs_continuous.name: Line vs Continuous Spectra
line_vs_continuous.correct: Line spectra show discrete wavelengths because electrons can only transition between specific energy levels. Continuous spectra come from hot solids.

line spectra from hot solids.error: Hot solids produce continuous spectra, not line spectra.
line spectra from hot solids.fix: Line spectra come from gases where atoms are isolated.
line spectra from hot solids.action: Incandescent bulb (solid filament) = continuous. Gas discharge tube = lines.

continuous spectra from gases.error: Gases produce line spectra because of quantised energy levels.
continuous spectra from gases.fix: In solids, energy bands overlap creating continuous emission.
continuous spectra from gases.action: Compare tungsten filament spectrum (continuous) vs hydrogen discharge (lines).

all spectra are continuous.error: Line spectra clearly show discrete wavelengths.
all spectra are continuous.fix: The gaps between lines are evidence of quantised energy levels.
all spectra are continuous.action: Look at hydrogen emission spectrum. Four distinct visible lines, not a rainbow.

persistent.gap: You are not distinguishing line and continuous spectra.
persistent.action: Gases = lines. Hot solids = continuous. Know why for each.

unique_spectra.name: Element-Specific Spectra
unique_spectra.formula: Each element has unique energy levels
unique_spectra.correct: Every element has a unique set of energy levels and therefore produces a unique line spectrum, like a fingerprint.

all elements have same spectra.error: Energy levels depend on nuclear charge and electron configuration.
all elements have same spectra.fix: Different elements have different energy level structures.
all elements have same spectra.action: Compare hydrogen (4 visible lines) vs helium (multiple lines). Clearly different.

spectra depend only on temperature.error: Temperature affects intensity, not which lines appear.
spectra depend only on temperature.fix: The wavelengths in a spectrum are determined by the element, not temperature.
spectra depend only on temperature.action: Hot or cold hydrogen shows the same line positions. Intensity changes, not wavelengths.

absorption and emission spectra differ.error: Same element absorbs and emits at the same wavelengths.
absorption and emission spectra differ.fix: Dark lines in absorption appear at same positions as bright lines in emission.
absorption and emission spectra differ.action: Solar absorption lines match laboratory emission lines for the same elements.

persistent.gap: You are not recognising that spectra identify elements.
persistent.action: Learn: each element has its own spectral fingerprint. This is how we identify elements in stars.

emission_spectrum_appearance.name: Emission Spectrum Appearance
emission_spectrum_appearance.correct: Emission spectra show bright coloured lines on a dark background. Each line corresponds to a specific photon energy.

dark lines on bright background.fix: Emission = light coming out = bright lines. Absorption = light blocked = dark lines.
dark lines on bright background.action: Emission spectra are like neon signs. Bright colours on darkness.

continuous rainbow.error: Gases produce discrete lines, not continuous spectra.
continuous rainbow.fix: Only specific wavelengths are emitted, corresponding to energy level differences.
continuous rainbow.action: Gas discharge tubes show distinct lines, not blended colours.

single colour only.error: Most elements have multiple possible transitions.
single colour only.fix: Multiple energy level differences give multiple spectral lines.
single colour only.action: Hydrogen has four visible lines. Sodium has several. Multiple transitions are possible.

persistent.gap: You are not visualising emission spectra correctly.
persistent.action: Find images of gas discharge spectra. Bright lines on dark = emission.

absorption_spectrum_appearance.name: Absorption Spectrum Appearance
absorption_spectrum_appearance.correct: Absorption spectra show dark lines on a continuous bright background. The dark lines indicate wavelengths absorbed by the gas.

bright lines on dark background.fix: Absorption removes light from a continuous source, creating dark gaps.
bright lines on dark background.action: Sunlight through gas shows dark lines where light was absorbed.

completely dark.error: Only specific wavelengths are absorbed, not all light.
completely dark.fix: Most wavelengths pass through. Only those matching energy gaps are absorbed.
completely dark.action: The continuous spectrum is mostly still there, just with dark lines removed.

no pattern.error: Dark lines appear at specific, predictable positions.
no pattern.fix: Same element always absorbs the same wavelengths.
no pattern.action: Fraunhofer lines in solar spectrum match known element spectra.

persistent.gap: You are not visualising absorption spectra correctly.
persistent.action: Dark lines on rainbow = absorption. The element removes specific colours.

gas_discharge_tube.name: Gas Discharge Tube
gas_discharge_tube.correct: In a gas discharge tube, electric current passes through low-pressure gas, exciting atoms. They emit photons as electrons return to lower states.

heating the gas.error: Excitation is electrical, not primarily thermal.
heating the gas.fix: Collisions with accelerated electrons excite the gas atoms.
heating the gas.action: Neon signs work at near room temperature. Electrical excitation, not heating.

chemical reaction.error: No chemical change occurs. Atoms remain the same element.
chemical reaction.fix: Electronic transitions are physical, not chemical processes.
chemical reaction.action: Same gas can be used indefinitely. No consumption of material.

continuous spectrum produced.fix: Isolated gas atoms have quantised levels, producing discrete lines.
continuous spectrum produced.action: Hydrogen discharge tube shows only four visible lines, not a continuous spectrum.

persistent.gap: You do not understand how gas discharge tubes work.
persistent.action: Electric current ‚Üí electrons collide with gas atoms ‚Üí excitation ‚Üí emission.

metal_vapour_lamp_operation.name: Metal Vapour Lamp Operation
metal_vapour_lamp_operation.correct: Metal vapour lamps vaporise a metal using a hot electric arc, then the metal atoms emit their characteristic spectral lines.

solid metal glowing.error: The metal must be vaporised to produce line spectrum.
solid metal glowing.fix: Solid metals produce continuous spectra. Gaseous atoms produce lines.
solid metal glowing.action: The metal is heated until it becomes a gas, then it emits like any gas discharge.

electric current through solid wire.error: That would be an incandescent bulb with continuous spectrum.
electric current through solid wire.fix: Metal vapour lamps use an arc discharge through metal vapour.
electric current through solid wire.action: Compare: incandescent = solid filament = continuous. Vapour lamp = gas = lines.

same as all gas discharge tubes.error: Metal vapour lamps require vaporisation step, unlike simple gas tubes.
same as all gas discharge tubes.fix: Metals are not gaseous at room temperature, so must be vaporised first.
same as all gas discharge tubes.action: Neon is already a gas. Sodium must be heated to become vapour.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what makes metal vapour lamps special.
persistent.action: Key difference: metal must be vaporised. Once gaseous, it works like any discharge tube.

sodium_lamp_spectrum.name: Sodium Lamp Spectrum
sodium_lamp_spectrum.correct: Sodium vapour lamps produce characteristic yellow light dominated by two closely spaced lines near 589 nm.

white light.error: Sodium produces yellow, not white light.
white light.fix: The dominant transition produces yellow photons. Other lines are weaker.
white light.action: Sodium street lamps have distinctive yellow colour. Not white like LEDs.

single wavelength only.error: Sodium has multiple lines, but yellow dominates.
single wavelength only.fix: There are other transitions, but the 589 nm doublet is most intense.
single wavelength only.action: Look up sodium spectrum. Multiple lines exist, but yellow is strongest.

continuous spectrum.error: Like all gas discharge, sodium produces line spectrum.
continuous spectrum.fix: Vaporised sodium atoms emit at discrete wavelengths only.
continuous spectrum.action: Through a spectroscope, sodium light shows distinct lines, not a rainbow.

persistent.gap: You do not know sodium's characteristic spectrum.
persistent.action: Sodium = yellow (589 nm). This is why sodium street lamps look yellow-orange.

energy_level_diagram.name: Reading Energy Level Diagrams
energy_level_diagram.formula: Arrows show transitions, length shows photon energy
energy_level_diagram.correct: On energy level diagrams, downward arrows represent emission, upward arrows represent absorption. Arrow length indicates photon energy.

upward arrows for emission.error: Emission involves dropping down in energy.
upward arrows for emission.fix: Downward arrow = electron loses energy = photon emitted.
upward arrows for emission.action: Draw an arrow from n=3 to n=2. That arrow represents emission.

arrow length is arbitrary.error: Longer arrows mean larger energy differences.
arrow length is arbitrary.fix: Photon energy equals the energy gap, which is the arrow length on scale diagrams.
arrow length is arbitrary.action: Compare arrow from n=4 to n=1 vs n=4 to n=3. First is longer = more energetic photon.

arrows show electron path.error: Arrows show energy change, not physical movement.
arrows show electron path.fix: Electrons do not literally travel along the arrow path.
arrows show electron path.action: Energy diagrams are abstract. Arrows indicate state changes, not trajectories.

persistent.gap: You cannot correctly interpret energy level diagrams.
persistent.action: Practice: for each arrow, identify if it is emission or absorption, and calculate photon energy.

ionisation_energy.name: Ionisation Energy
ionisation_energy.formula: Energy to remove electron from atom
ionisation_energy.correct: Ionisation energy is the minimum energy required to completely remove an electron from the ground state, freeing it from the atom.

energy to excite to next level.error: That is excitation energy, not ionisation.
energy to excite to next level.fix: Ionisation means removing the electron entirely, not just exciting it.
energy to excite to next level.action: Ionised atom has one fewer electron. Excited atom still has all electrons.

energy released when electron captured.error: Ionisation requires energy input, not release.
energy released when electron captured.fix: Breaking the electron free requires work against the attractive force.
energy released when electron captured.action: Think of escape velocity. Energy must be added to ionise.

same for all elements.error: Ionisation energy depends on nuclear charge and electron configuration.
same for all elements.fix: Hydrogen is 13.6 eV. Other elements differ based on their structure.
same for all elements.action: Compare ionisation energies across the periodic table. They vary significantly.

persistent.action: Ionisation = electron removed from atom. Excitation = electron raised to higher bound state.

energy_levels.title: Understanding Atomic Energy Levels
energy_levels.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of electron energy levels in atoms.

sentences.text: Electrons in atoms can only exist at {{d1}} energy levels, meaning they cannot have energies {{d2}} these allowed values.

d1.tooltip: Quantised means limited to specific values.

d2.tooltip: Electrons cannot exist in the gaps between levels.

sentences.text: The {{d3}} is the lowest energy level an electron can occupy, labelled n = {{d4}}. This is the most {{d5}} state for an atom.

d5.tooltip: Atoms naturally settle into the lowest energy configuration.

sentences.text: When an electron is in an energy level above the ground state, it is in an {{d6}} state. These states are {{d7}} and the electron will eventually return to a lower level.

d6.tooltip: Excited means raised above the ground level.

d7.tooltip: Higher energy states tend to decay to lower ones.

emission_spectra.title: Understanding Emission Spectra
emission_spectra.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how emission spectra are produced.

sentences.text: An emission spectrum is produced when electrons transition from {{d1}} to {{d2}} energy levels, {{d3}} a photon in the process.

d1.tooltip: Think about the direction: emission releases energy.

d3.tooltip: The energy difference is released as a photon.

sentences.text: The energy of the emitted photon equals the {{d4}} between the two energy levels involved. This can be calculated using Eph = {{d5}}.

d4.tooltip: Photon energy comes from the gap between levels.

d5.tooltip: Delta E represents the change in energy.

sentences.text: Emission spectra appear as {{d6}} lines on a {{d7}} background, with each line corresponding to a specific electron transition.

d6.tooltip: Light is being emitted, so the lines are bright.

d7.tooltip: Only specific wavelengths are emitted, rest is dark.

absorption_spectra.title: Understanding Absorption Spectra
absorption_spectra.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how absorption spectra are produced.

sentences.text: An absorption spectrum is produced when electrons {{d1}} photons and transition from {{d2}} to {{d3}} energy levels.

d2.tooltip: Electrons start at lower levels before absorbing.

d3.tooltip: Absorbed energy raises the electron to a higher level.

sentences.text: For absorption to occur, the photon energy must {{d4}} match the energy gap between two levels. Photons with wrong energies will {{d5}} the atom unchanged.

d4.tooltip: Quantised levels require exact energy matching.

d5.tooltip: Wrong energy photons are not absorbed.

sentences.text: Absorption spectra appear as {{d6}} lines on a {{d7}} background. The dark lines indicate wavelengths that were {{d8}} by the atoms.

d6.tooltip: Light is removed, leaving dark gaps.

d7.tooltip: Original light source is continuous; dark lines appear where light was removed.

d8.tooltip: Dark lines show where photons were taken in.

metal_vapour_lamps.title: Understanding Metal Vapour Lamps
metal_vapour_lamps.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how metal vapour lamps produce light.

sentences.text: In a gas discharge tube, an electric current passes through a {{d1}}-pressure gas, causing collisions that {{d2}} the gas atoms to higher energy levels.

d1.tooltip: Low pressure allows electrons to accelerate between collisions.

d2.tooltip: Energy from collisions raises electrons to higher levels.

sentences.text: Metal vapour lamps differ from simple gas tubes because metals must first be {{d3}} using a hot electric arc before they can emit their characteristic {{d4}} spectrum.

d3.tooltip: Metals are not gases at room temperature.

d4.tooltip: Gaseous atoms produce discrete spectral lines.

sentences.text: Sodium vapour lamps produce characteristic {{d5}} light, dominated by emission near {{d6}} nm. This is why sodium street lamps have their distinctive colour.

d5.tooltip: Think of the colour of sodium street lamps.

d6.tooltip: Yellow light has wavelength around 580-590 nm.

energy_levels.title: Applying Energy Level Concepts
energy_levels.instructions: Apply your understanding of energy levels to these scenarios.

sentences.text: The quantisation of electron energy levels explains why atomic spectra show {{d1}} wavelengths rather than a continuous range. Each element has {{d2}} energy levels and therefore a {{d3}} spectrum.

d1.tooltip: Discrete energy gaps give discrete photon energies.

d2.tooltip: Different nuclear charges mean different energy level structures.

d3.tooltip: Each element's spectrum acts like a fingerprint.

sentences.text: When hydrogen is excited to the n = 4 level, it can return to the ground state by emitting {{d4}} photon(s) directly, or by a series of {{d5}} transitions emitting {{d6}} photons.

d4.tooltip: Direct transition n=4 to n=1 is a single jump.

d6.tooltip: Each step down produces a separate photon.

sentences.text: If an electron absorbs a photon with energy {{d7}} than the ionisation energy, the electron will be {{d8}} from the atom entirely, rather than transitioning to an excited state.

d7.tooltip: Ionisation requires at least the ionisation energy.

d8.tooltip: The electron leaves the atom completely.

emission_spectra.title: Analysing Emission Spectra
emission_spectra.instructions: Apply your understanding to analyse emission spectra scenarios.

sentences.text: In a hydrogen discharge tube, the visible emission lines correspond to transitions ending at the n = {{d1}} level. The red line at 656 nm comes from the transition n = {{d2}} to n = 2.

d1.tooltip: Visible hydrogen lines are the Balmer series, ending at n=2.

d2.tooltip: The smallest energy gap to n=2 produces the longest wavelength (red).

sentences.text: The photon with the {{d3}} wavelength in an emission spectrum corresponds to the {{d4}} energy transition. Using E = hc/Œª, shorter wavelength means {{d5}} photon energy.

d3.tooltip: Energy and wavelength are inversely related.

d4.tooltip: Big energy gap = short wavelength photon.

sentences.text: Scientists can identify elements in distant stars by comparing their emission spectra to {{d6}} spectra measured in the laboratory. Each element's spectral lines are like a unique {{d7}}.

absorption_spectra.title: Analysing Absorption Spectra
absorption_spectra.instructions: Apply your understanding to analyse absorption spectra scenarios.

sentences.text: The dark lines in the Sun's spectrum, called {{d1}} lines, occur because cooler gases in the Sun's atmosphere {{d2}} specific wavelengths from the continuous spectrum below.

d1.tooltip: Named after the scientist who catalogued them.

d2.tooltip: Dark lines show where light was removed.

sentences.text: For the same element, the dark lines in its absorption spectrum appear at {{d3}} wavelengths as the bright lines in its emission spectrum. This is because both involve the {{d4}} energy level transitions.

d3.tooltip: Same energy gaps mean same wavelengths.

d4.tooltip: Absorption and emission involve the same energy differences.

sentences.text: After absorbing a photon, the excited atom quickly {{d5}} by emitting a photon in a {{d6}} direction. This is why the original beam shows dark lines‚Äîthe absorbed light is scattered away.

d5.tooltip: Excited states are unstable and decay.

d6.tooltip: Re-emitted photons go in all directions, not just the original beam direction.

metal_vapour_lamps.title: Analysing Metal Vapour Lamps
metal_vapour_lamps.instructions: Apply your understanding to analyse metal vapour lamp scenarios.

sentences.text: Mercury vapour lamps produce {{d1}} light because mercury's emission spectrum includes strong lines in the blue and {{d2}} regions of the visible spectrum.

d1.tooltip: Mercury has different energy levels than sodium.

d2.tooltip: Mercury strongly emits in the UV, which is converted or filtered.

sentences.text: Unlike an incandescent bulb that produces a {{d3}} spectrum from a hot solid filament, metal vapour lamps produce {{d4}} spectra because they use gaseous atoms.
The colour of a metal vapour lamp is determined by the {{d5}} of the metal atoms, not by the {{d6}} of the electric discharge.

d5.tooltip: Energy levels determine which wavelengths are emitted.

d6.tooltip: Temperature affects intensity, not which wavelengths appear.

energy_levels.title: Mastering Energy Level Concepts
energy_levels.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of atomic energy levels.

sentences.text: A common misconception is that electrons can have any energy value. In reality, the wave nature of electrons means only {{d1}} can form around the nucleus, restricting electrons to {{d2}} energy levels.

d1.tooltip: Electrons behave as waves that must fit integer wavelengths around orbit.

d2.tooltip: Standing wave requirement means only certain energies are allowed.

sentences.text: On an energy level diagram, the {{d3}} represents the energy needed to completely remove an electron. Energy levels are typically shown with the ground state at the {{d4}}.

d4.tooltip: Lower energy is conventionally shown at the bottom.

sentences.text: When reading an energy diagram, an arrow pointing {{d5}} represents emission with photon energy equal to the {{d6}} of the arrow on the energy scale.

d5.tooltip: Down means dropping in energy, releasing a photon.

d6.tooltip: Arrow length represents energy difference between levels.

emission_spectra.title: Mastering Emission Spectra
emission_spectra.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of emission spectra production.

sentences.text: From an excited state at n = 5, hydrogen can emit {{d1}} different photon energies as it returns to the ground state through various pathways. The number of possible transitions from level n equals n(n-1)/2, giving {{d2}} for n = 5.
The emission spectrum of a hot, dense solid appears {{d3}} because the atoms interact so strongly that energy levels {{d4}}, removing the discrete gaps.

d3.tooltip: Dense matter produces continuous, not line, spectra.

d4.tooltip: Close atoms cause energy bands rather than discrete levels.

sentences.text: The helium emission spectrum was first observed during a solar {{d5}} before helium was discovered on Earth. This demonstrates how spectra can identify elements even at great {{d6}}.

d5.tooltip: The Sun's chromosphere is visible during eclipses.

d6.tooltip: Spectroscopy identifies elements in distant stars.

absorption_spectra.title: Mastering Absorption Spectra
absorption_spectra.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of absorption spectra production.

sentences.text: Astronomers use absorption spectra to identify elements in planetary atmospheres. When white light from a star passes through a planet's atmosphere, {{d1}} wavelengths are removed, appearing as {{d2}} lines.

d1.tooltip: Only wavelengths matching energy gaps are absorbed.

d2.tooltip: Absorbed wavelengths appear as dark gaps.

sentences.text: The fact that absorption and emission lines occur at identical wavelengths for a given element is direct evidence that atomic transitions involve the {{d3}} energy differences regardless of direction. This is required by {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: The energy gap is fixed by the atomic structure.

d4.tooltip: Photon energy must exactly match the transition energy.

sentences.text: A cool gas cloud in front of a hot star produces {{d5}} spectrum because the cloud absorbs light from the star's {{d6}} emission.

d5.tooltip: Cool gas absorbs from the continuous background.

d6.tooltip: Hot dense stars produce continuous spectra.

metal_vapour_lamps.title: Mastering Metal Vapour Lamps
metal_vapour_lamps.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of metal vapour lamp production.

sentences.text: The aurora australis produces colours when solar wind particles excite {{d1}} atoms in Earth's upper atmosphere. The green colour comes from oxygen at around {{d2}} nm, demonstrating emission spectra in nature.

d1.tooltip: Oxygen and nitrogen in Earth's atmosphere are excited.

d2.tooltip: Green auroral light has a specific wavelength determined by oxygen energy levels.

sentences.text: A key advantage of metal vapour lamps over incandescent bulbs is their higher {{d3}} because energy is released at specific wavelengths rather than as broad {{d4}} radiation.

d3.tooltip: Less energy is wasted as invisible wavelengths.

d4.tooltip: Incandescent bulbs waste much energy as heat and infrared.

sentences.text: To determine if a street lamp is sodium or mercury vapour, observe its spectrum through a {{d5}}. Sodium shows strong {{d6}} lines while mercury shows bluish and UV lines.

d5.tooltip: A spectroscope separates light into its component wavelengths.

d6.tooltip: Sodium's characteristic emission is yellow at 589 nm.
